claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination improves tumor sensitivity to immune checkpoint blockade (anti-PD-L1).

evidence.quote: The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and induces a type I interferon response within the tumor.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination correlates with improved survival outcomes in patients receiving ICI treatment.

evidence.quote: Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination increases the diversity of antigens presented on MHC-I, enhancing tumor visibility.

evidence.quote: A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
